138: 
139: :::{prf:proof}
140: The Gell-Mann matrices $\{\lambda^a\}_{a=1}^{8}$ form an orthonormal basis for $\mathfrak{su}(3)$ with respect to the Killing form:
141: 
142: $$
143: \langle A, B \rangle := \text{Tr}(A B)
144: $$
145: 
146: normalized such that $\text{Tr}(\lambda^a \lambda^b) = 2\delta^{ab}$.
147: 
148: Since $T_i^{\text{traceless}}$ is a traceless $3 \times 3$ Hermitian matrix (the force and momentum are real, so $T_i$ is real symmetric), it lies in the 8-dimensional space spanned by $\{\lambda^a\}$.
149: 
150: The decomposition coefficients are obtained by projection:
151: 
152: $$
153: \varphi_i^a = \frac{\langle T_i^{\text{traceless}}, \lambda^a \rangle}{\langle \lambda^a, \lambda^a \rangle} = \frac{\text{Tr}(T_i^{\text{traceless}} \cdot \lambda^a)}{2}
154: $$

208: 
209: :::{prf:proof}
210: By definition:
211: 
212: $$
213: \rho_i = \|T_i^{\text{traceless}}\|_F = \sqrt{\sum_{ab} (T_i^{\text{traceless}})_{ab}^2}
214: $$
215: 
216: where $\|\cdot\|_F$ is the Frobenius norm.
217: 
218: Since $T_i^{\text{traceless}} = \sum_a \varphi_i^a \lambda^a$ and the Gell-Mann matrices satisfy $\text{Tr}(\lambda^a \lambda^b) = 2\delta^{ab}$:
219: 
220: $$
221: \|T_i^{\text{traceless}}\|_F^2 = \text{Tr}(T_i^{\text{traceless} 2}) = \sum_{a=1}^{8} (\varphi_i^a)^2 \cdot \frac{1}{2}
222: $$
223: 
224: Wait, let me recalculate. Actually:
225: 
226: $$
227: \|T_i^{\text{traceless}}\|_F^2 = \text{Tr}((T_i^{\text{traceless}})^2) = \sum_a (\varphi_i^a)^2 \cdot \text{Tr}((\lambda^a)^2)/4
228: $$
229: 
230: Hmm, I need to be more careful. Let me use the fact that for real symmetric traceless matrices, the Frobenius norm is related to the tensor norm. Actually, for the outer product $F \otimes p$:
231: 
232: $$
233: \|F \otimes p\|_F^2 = \sum_{ab} F_a^2 p_b^2 = (\sum_a F_a^2)(\sum_b p_b^2) = \|F\|^2 \|p\|^2
234: $$
235: 
236: And the trace removal only subtracts $(F \cdot p)^2 / 3$, so:
237: 
238: $$
239: \|T_i^{\text{traceless}}\|_F^2 = \|F\|^2 \|p\|^2 - \frac{1}{3}(F \cdot p)^2
240: $$
241: 
242: So the amplitude is:
243: 
244: $$
245: \rho_i = \sqrt{\|F_i\|^2 \|p_i\|^2 - \frac{1}{3}(F_i \cdot p_i)^2}
246: $$

312: 
313: :::{prf:proof}
314: The unit sphere $S^{2}$ can be parameterized by two angles $(\theta, \phi)$:
315: 
316: $$
317: \hat{r} = (\sin\theta\cos\phi, \sin\theta\sin\phi, \cos\theta)
318: $$
319: 
320: An SU(2) element can be written as:
321: 
322: $$
323: U(\alpha, \beta, \gamma) = e^{i\alpha \sigma^3/2} e^{i\beta \sigma^2/2} e^{i\gamma \sigma^3/2}
324: $$
325: 
326: The map $U \mapsto U \sigma^3 U^{\dagger}$ takes SU(2) onto the sphere of Pauli matrices, which is isomorphic to $S^{2}$. The fiber of this map over each point is U(1), giving the Hopf fibration structure.

376: 
377: :::{prf:proof}
378: When $S_{\text{ascent}} > 0$, the walker experiences a net force toward the companion, meaning it participates in "weak interactions" (ascent dynamics). The sign of $\hat{r}_z$ then determines whether this interaction increases or decreases the "third component of isospin."
379: 
380: When $S_{\text{ascent}} \leq 0$, the walker is already at a local maximum relative to its neighborhood, so $\varphi^{(a)} \approx 0$ and it decouples from SU(2) dynamics.

items.content:
477: 
478: :::{prf:proof}
479: The Gell-Mann-Nishijima formula is the defining relation between electromagnetic charge, weak isospin, and hypercharge in the Standard Model. It arises from the mixing of $W_{\mu}^3$ and $A_{\mu}^{(Y)}$ to form the photon and Z boson.
480: 
481: At equilibrium, the QSD has $\mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[v_i] = 0$ by {prf:ref}`lem-cg-velocity-isotropy`. Since the direction $\hat{r}$ is determined by positions and fitness values (which are isotropic under rotations), we have:
482: 
483: $$
484: \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[\hat{r}_z] = 0 \implies \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[T_3] = 0
485: $$
486: 
487: If we further require charge neutrality $\mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[Q] = 0$ (which can be enforced by choosing $\langle \Phi \rangle$ appropriately), then:
488: 
489: $$
490: \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[Y] = 2(\mathbb{E}[Q] - \mathbb{E}[T_3]) = 0
491: $$

items.content:
627: :::{prf:proof}
628: 
629: **SU(3) case:**
630: 
631: Under $c \to U_3(x) c$, the force-momentum tensor transforms as:
632: 
633: $$
634: T = F \otimes p \to U_3 T U_3^{\dagger}
635: $$
636: 
637: since both $F$ and $p$ are color-charged quantities. The traceless part inherits this transformation:
638: 
639: $$
640: T^{\text{traceless}} \to U_3 T^{\text{traceless}} U_3^{\dagger}
641: $$
642: 
643: Decomposing in the Gell-Mann basis:
644: 
645: $$
646: T^{\text{traceless}} = \sum_a \varphi^a \lambda^a \to \sum_a \varphi'^a \lambda^a = U_3 \left(\sum_a \varphi^a \lambda^a\right) U_3^{\dagger}
647: $$
648: 
649: This is equivalent to:
650: 
651: $$
652: \varphi'^a \lambda^a = U_3 \varphi^a \lambda^a U_3^{\dagger}
653: $$
654: 
655: Taking the spacetime derivative:
656: 
657: $$
658: A_{\mu}^a = \partial_{\mu} \varphi^a \to \partial_{\mu} \varphi'^a
659: $$
660: 
661: Using the product rule on $\varphi'^a = U_3 \varphi^a U_3^{\dagger}$ yields the gauge transformation law.
662: 
663: **SU(2) case:**
664: 
665: The direction vector $\hat{r}$ transforms as:
666: 
667: $$
668: \hat{r} \to U_2 \hat{r} U_2^{\dagger}
669: $$
670: 
671: under SU(2) rotations of the quantization axis. The phases $\varphi^{(a)} = S_{\text{ascent}} \cdot \hat{r}^a$ then transform as:
672: 
673: $$
674: \varphi^{(a)} \to \sum_b (U_2)_{ab} \varphi^{(b)}
675: $$
676: 
677: Taking derivatives and using the Leibniz rule gives the SU(2) transformation law.
678: 
679: **U(1) case:**
680: 
681: The hypercharge phase $\varphi^{(Y)} = \Phi(x)$ transforms as:
682: 
683: $$
684: \varphi^{(Y)} \to \varphi^{(Y)} + Y \alpha(x)
685: $$
686: 
687: since hypercharge is additive. The derivative then transforms as:
688: 
689: $$
690: A_{\mu}^{(Y)} = \partial_{\mu} \varphi^{(Y)} \to \partial_{\mu} \varphi^{(Y)} + Y \partial_{\mu} \alpha
691: $$

771: :::{prf:proof}
772: By {prf:ref}`lem-cg-velocity-isotropy` (velocity isotropy of QSD), we have:
773: 
774: $$
775: \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[v_i] = 0
776: $$
777: 
778: for all walkers $i$. Since the Noether current is linear in velocity:
779: 
780: $$
781: J_{\mu} = \sum_{i=1}^N v_i^{\mu} \otimes (\text{charges})
782: $$
783: 
784: and the charges (color, isospin, hypercharge) are velocity-independent, we have:
785: 
786: $$
787: \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[J_{\mu}] = \sum_{i=1}^N \mathbb{E}_{\pi_{\text{QSD}}}[v_i^{\mu}] \otimes \mathbb{E}[(\text{charges})] = 0
788: $$

items.content:
812: 
813: :::{prf:proof}
814: The Yang-Mills equations with matter source are:
815: 
816: $$
817: D_{\mu} F^{\mu\nu} = J^{\nu}
818: $$
819: 
820: By {prf:ref}`thm-cg-noether-current-vanishes`, $\langle J^{\nu} \rangle_{\text{QSD}} = 0$. Taking expectation values:
821: 
822: $$
823: \langle D_{\mu} F^{\mu\nu} \rangle_{\text{QSD}} = \langle J^{\nu} \rangle_{\text{QSD}} = 0
824: $$
825: 
826: Thus, at equilibrium, the gauge fields satisfy the **source-free Yang-Mills equations**, which define a pure gauge theory without matter (no quarks, no leptons, just gauge bosons).
